I found this article interesting from a perspective of big fund managers responsible for 401kaput money switching from our beaten-up and maxed out equity markets to commodity investing, commonly accepted as carrying a risk factor right up there with roulette. 
 
 http://www.reuters.com/financeNewsArticle.jhtml?type=businessNews&storyID=5180890

Even though the oil companies have reportedly made record profits recently (in the billions) I believe they will find a way to keep prices high during the summer driving season.
 
 I've cut down on my driving and pulled out the old back-up Honda to spend less on gasoline.
 
 I know this is not exactly on your topic of investment strategies, but I say it only to point out that I'm preparing for total collapse of my 401k.
 
 Maybe we're headed for the ultimate redistribution of wealth...we'll all soon have nothing!

 You see Jim life is not cracked up to the Concevative life style that you because they are doing you in. Haaa Haaa Haaa Haaa Haaaa. 401k what a joke I got rid of mine 10 years ago because I smelled a rat with that one.

Exxon is poised to pass Wal-Mart as America's biggest company purely from crude price increases.
 
 I often wonder what people have against companies making profits as that's what makes our country function. Our major problems with oil as consumers are multiple; increased domestic and international demand, the weak dollar, and our ME aggression. No short-term relief is in sight from any of those factors. 
 
 With demand forecast doing nothing but increasing, I can understand fund managers going to a commodity on a short-term profit basis, but long-term commodity investment would scare me to death. Especially with the always present danger of another terrorist attack, which would again take our economy to the mat. Most companies are now dusting off 2001 pro-formas for 2005 projections. 
 
 Another side issue with oil prices escalating is the way our government fiefdom reports inflation for political purposes. Transportation and food costs are reported separately, so inflation appears in line with our pathetic growth numbers. When you're using government vehicles and eating in a government dining room, there's not much need to be concerned with those increases.
